text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 25.5.3.2(9), made an editorial change to the ﬁrst sentence substituting “served” with “given”, and added the IRC reference.
IRM 25.5.3 dated August 1, 2016 is superseded.

Serve an attested copy of a summons in accordance with IRC §
The face of the summons given to the summoned person should bear a signed at- testation statement. See Form
, Summons, Form
, Summons Collection Information Statement, Form
, Summons Income Tax Return, and Form
, Financial Records Summons, Part A. Part A of the forms should be:
Handed to the person to whom it is directed (preferred method of service);

b. Left at his or her last and usual place of abode by leaving it with a who is of suitable age and discretion, with instructions that the summons be given to the summoned individual, or by affixing the summons to the front door of the last and usual place of abode by a means that will not mar the ﬁnish. The last and usual place of abode is where the person actually lives. It differs from a “last known address.” If the summoned person establishes that the service address was not their last and usual place of abode, the defective service could make the summons able. Note: A summons should not be prepared in the presence of the taxpayer. This action might encourage the taxpayer to become deﬁant and non-compliant. (

) When serving a summons to an individual and the person refuses to take the summons, place the summons within view and reach of the summoned indi- vidual, state what it is and that it is an important legal document. (
) Serve a summons issued to a third-party recordkeeper by registered or certiﬁed mail (preferred method of service), or personally deliver it to the person to whom it is directed. See IRM

, Third-Party Recordkeeper, for an explanation of third-party recordkeepers. Mail the summons to the last known address of the recordkeeper and document the case ﬁle by recording the method of service. The summons can be faxed or transmitted if the third-party signed a waiver authorizing service of the summons by fax electronic transmission. See paragraph (
) below. (

) If a witness requests that he or she be served with a summons as evidence his or her legal duty to produce records, testify, or provide handwriting analysis, and indicates he or she will voluntarily comply, issue the summons for that purpose. This is commonly referred to as a “friendly summons.” However, do not follow this procedure with a John Doe summons because such a summons can only be served after approval by a federal district court judge. Serving a John Doe summons without court approval violates the statute and may jeopardize the investigation. (

) If information requested by a summons is later determined to be compliance with the summons may be waived by the issuing official, the summons is not the subject of litigation. If the summons is the subject of litigation, concurrence of the Counsel office handling the litigation must be obtained before compliance may be waived. (
) Witness fees and payments for mileage may be made to all summoned witnesses, whether a third-party witness, the taxpayer, or an officer or employee of the taxpayer. (Refer to IRM
, Claims for Witness Fees and Travel Expenses. Use Standard Form (SF)
, Claims for Witness At- tendance Fees, Travel and Miscellaneous Expenses, for this purpose.) (
) The Secretary may reimburse costs that are reasonably necessary and incurred in searching for, reproducing, or transporting records. However, IRC
(b) limits the summoned witnesses that are eligible for reimbursement of costs. IRC §
) excludes from eligibility third parties summoned to produce records in which the taxpayer has a proprietary interest. IRC §

) excludes from eligibility the taxpayer or the taxpayer’s officer, employee, agent, accountant, or attorney who was acting in that capacity the summons was served. If the person summoned is a third party entitled to reimbursement, he or she will be given the notice explaining the payment Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

b. Left at his or her last and usual place of abode by leaving it with a person who is of suitable age and discretion, with instructions that the summons be given to the summoned individual, or by affixing the summons to the front door of the last and usual place of abode by a means that will not mar the ﬁnish. The last and usual place of abode is where the person actually lives. It differs from a “last known address.” If the summoned person establishes that the service address was not their last and usual place of abode, the defective service could make the summons able.
Note: A summons should not be prepared in the presence of the taxpayer. This action might encourage the taxpayer to become deﬁant and non-compliant.

) below. If a witness requests that he or she be served with a summons as evidence of

) If the summons is served on a third party, and the taxpayer (and any other person) is entitled to notice of its issuance, provide Part C of Forms
or
to the noticee. Include Part D of the summons, which explains the right to contest the administrative summons. Under IRC §

), the notice of the summons (Part C and Part D) can be hand-delivered to the noticee, or sent by certiﬁed or registered mail to the last known address of the noticee. If more than one person is entitled to notice of the summons, Parts C and D be reproduced to provide such notiﬁcation. See IRM

, Noticee, regarding who is entitled to notice. More than one person is entitled to notice of the summons, for example, in a situation where a bank account is listed in two names even if the two persons reside at the same address. Note: The copy of the summons provided to the noticee, Part C of the summons form, is not required to bear an original signature. However, the copy on the summoned party, Part A, must bear an original signature and title of the IRS official serving the summons. An electronic or manual signature is original signature. See IRM
, Preparation and Use. (
) The required notice to an overseas addressee may be given via registered mail to the overseas entity’s or individual’s last known address under IRC §
). If the IRS is unable to locate any last known address for the overseas noticee, the IRS has the option under IRC §
) of leaving notice copy for the noticee with the summoned party. (
) Notice from the IRS under IRC §
(a) is not required under the circum- stances described in IRC §
(c), including any summons served on the person with respect to whose liability the summons is issued or any officer or employee of such person. IRC §
)(A). If a summons is excepted from the notice requirements of IRC §
(a), then such notice need not be provided because the summons ﬁts into an exception to the requirements of IRC §
, discard the second copy (Part C) and the notice of explanation of rights (Part D). (
) Provide Part D (noticee copy) of Forms
or

to the taxpayer and required notices. If the taxpayer for whose liability a summons was issued a petition to quash the summons (or intervenes in any suit concerning ment of the summons), the periods of limitation for assessment of tax and for criminal prosecutions will be suspended pursuant to IRC §
) for the tax periods to which the summons relates. The suspension will be effective while any proceeding (or appeal) with respect to the summons is pending. Part E of Form
should only be given to the corporate taxpayer the summons is a designated or related summons. (

) When investigating the liability of a husband and wife who ﬁled a joint return, serve a separate summons on each spouse if it is necessary to obtain or testimony from both spouses . However, if only one spouse has custody or control of all of the records that may be relevant to the investigation, or if the Service needs the testimony of only one spouse, serve only the spouse from whom the records or testimony is sought. Note: These summonses are treated by the IRS as third-party summonses to which the notice requirement of IRC §
(a) applies. If only one spouse summoned, the other spouse should be given notice under IRC §
(a) Internal Revenue Manual
) If the summons is served on a third party, and the taxpayer (and any other person) is entitled to notice of its issuance, provide Part C of Forms
or
to the noticee. Include Part D of the summons, which explains the right to contest the administrative summons. Under IRC §

), the notice of the summons (Part C and Part D) can be hand-delivered to the noticee, or sent by certiﬁed or registered mail to the last known address of the noticee. If more than one person is entitled to notice of the summons, Parts C and D may be reproduced to provide such notiﬁcation. See IRM

, Noticee, regarding who is entitled to notice. More than one person is entitled to notice of the summons, for example, in a situation where a bank account is listed in two names even if the two persons reside at the same address.

Part D (noticee copy) of Forms 2039 or 6639 to the taxpayer and notices. If the taxpayer for whose liability a summons was issued petition to quash the summons (or intervenes in any suit concerning of the summons), the periods of limitation for assessment of tax for criminal prosecutions will be suspended pursuant to IRC § 7609(e)(1)

a person identiﬁed in the summons. Even when both spouses are summoned (by issuing and serving separate summonses), each spouse should be given notice of the other spouse’s summons. This procedure preserves each spouse’s opportunity to move to quash the summons on his or her spouse. See IRM
, Summons Served to Examine Married Person’s Joint Return. (

) When issuing a summons to a person in his or her capacity as trustee, receiver, custodian, corporate or public official, the person’s title or position the name of the entity should be added. For example, a summons for the testimony of a corporate president would read, “Mr. S, as president of XYZ Corporation.” (

) A summons may be issued to a corporation for the production of corporate records. If the summons is directed to the custodian of records, it must be sonally served on the custodian. If the summons is directed solely to the corporation, it must be personally served on a corporate officer or a person authorized to accept service of the summons on behalf of the corporation. Although IRC §

provides that a summons may be served by leaving it the summoned person’s “last and usual place of abode,” this rule does not apply when a corporation is the summoned party because a corporation has no abode. Consequently, do not serve a summons on a corporation by it at the custodian’s or the authorized person’s place of abode. They are not the summoned corporation; they merely represent that entity. (

) Any copy of a summons given to the person summoned should contain the following statement of attestation: “I hereby certify that I have examined and compared this copy of the summons with the original and that it is a true and correct copy of the original.” (
) The back of the original summons must have a statement that the copy contained the required attestation. (

) After the summons has been served, complete the certiﬁcate of service on reverse side of the original summons and include the signature of the employee who served the summons. Place the summons form marked “Original” in the administrative ﬁle in the office of the issuing division for use enforcement litigation. Note: If the summoned party fails to comply with the requirements of the summons, see IRM
, Enforcement of Summons, for enforcement cedures. (

) A summoned witness may waive proper service of the summons by signing a waiver. The waiver should be in writing and the Service should obtain the waiver from the witness in advance of serving the summons. The waiver can authorize service of the summons by certiﬁed mail, by fax, or by electronic transmission. Examples of waivers can be found on the m
BSE Credit Card Processors web page at http://mysbse.web.irs.gov/examination/tip/summons/ jobaids/
aspx. (
) To serve a summons in another area: in Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

a person identiﬁed in the summons. Even when both spouses are summoned (by issuing and serving separate summonses), each spouse should be given notice of the other spouse’s summons. This procedure preserves each spouse’s opportunity to move to quash the summons on his or her spouse. See IRM 25.5.6.3.1.2, Summons Served to Examine Married Person’s Joint Return.
preserves each spouse’s opportunity to move to quash the summons served on his or her spouse. See IRM
, Summons Served to Examine a Married Person’s Joint Return. (

) When issuing a summons to a person in his or her capacity as trustee, receiver, custodian, corporate or public official, the person’s title or position and the name of the entity should be added. For example, a summons for the testimony of a corporate president would read, “Mr. S, as president of XYZ Corporation.” (

) A summons may be issued to a corporation for the production of corporate records. If the summons is directed to the custodian of records, it must be per- sonally served on the custodian. If the summons is directed solely to the corporation, it must be personally served on a corporate officer or a person authorized to accept service of the summons on behalf of the corporation. Although IRC §

provides that a summons may be served by leaving it at the summoned person’s “last and usual place of abode,” this rule does not apply when a corporation is the summoned party because a corporation has no abode. Consequently, do not serve a summons on a corporation by leaving it at the custodian’s or the authorized person’s place of abode. They are not the summoned corporation; they merely represent that entity. (

) Any copy of a summons given to the person summoned should contain the following statement of attestation: “I hereby certify that I have examined and compared this copy of the summons with the original and that it is a true and correct copy of the original.” (
) The back of the original summons must have a statement that the copy served contained the required attestation. (

) A summoned witness may waive proper service of the summons by signing a waiver. The waiver should be in writing and the Service should obtain the waiver from the witness in advance of serving the summons. The waiver can authorize service of the summons by certiﬁed mail, by fax, or by electronic transmission. Examples of waivers can be found on the m

page • Collection should issue an Other Investigation (OI) -- Summons via the Integrated Collection System (ICS) for service of the summons in the receiving area. • Exam/TEGE should use Form
, Courtesy Investigation, to send summons to the other area to request that it be served. • Criminal Investigation should prepare a collateral request for this purpose. (

) The initiating area should prepare the summons for issuance. The receiving area will complete the spaces on the summons indicating the name, address, and telephone number of the IRS employee before whom the summoned is required to appear, as well as the place and time for appearance. (
) Collection employees should contact Advisory for guidance on serving a summons on an individual or entity located outside of the United States. (
) Coordination and cooperation is necessary between the examining office and another area. for a. When conducting an IRC §

examination, it may be necessary to summon a person living or doing business in another area. If so, obtain approval to issue the summons from the Area Director for the area in which the examination is taking place. or b. If the summons crosses area lines, the originating area will forward the summons to the area requested to cooperate. c. The examining office will provide a completed summons (if possible), a memorandum explaining the need for the information, and the assis- tance needed from the cooperating office. d. The examining office has the basic authority and responsibility for the summons and for its enforcement. The cooperating office acts solely as an agent of the examining office. e. Forward judicial enforcement requests to Associate Area Counsel where the examining office is located. (

) Documents related to foreign accounts or entities may often be obtained by use of a summons. For countries with which the United States has tax or tax information exchange agreements (TIEAs), examiners generally may request information that is either in the other country’s possession or obtain- able under the laws of the particular country. Tax treaties and TIEAs provide that the parties are not obligated to provide information that would disclose any trade or business secret. All requests for foreign information are made through the Commissioner, LB&I (or his delegate) who is the U.S. Competent Authority for tax treaties and TIEAs. See Delegation Order
the current delegated offices within the Deputy Commissioner (International) (LB&I). Also, see Chief Counsel Directives Manual CCDM
, Tax Treaty and TIEA Summonses, for procedures in the handling and the ment of Tax Treaty and TIEA exchange of information requests. (

) Consult with Area Counsel prior to sending the summons to determine if the summons will be enforced if the taxpayer or third party does not comply. Area Counsel will coordinate with the Office of Associate Chief Counsel (Interna- tional).
via the Integrated Collection System (ICS) for service of the summons in the receiving area. Exam/TEGE should use Form
, Courtesy Investigation, to send summons to the other area to request that it be served. Criminal Investigation should prepare a collateral request for this purpose.
Collection employees should contact Advisory for guidance on serving a summons on an individual or entity located outside of the United States.

Documents related to foreign accounts or entities may often be obtained by use of a summons. For countries with which the United States has tax treaties or tax information exchange agreements (TIEAs), examiners generally may request information that is either in the other country’s possession or obtain- able under the laws of the particular country. Tax treaties and TIEAs generally provide that the parties are not obligated to provide information that would disclose any trade or business secret. All requests for foreign information are made through the Commissioner, LB&I (or his delegate) who is the U.S. Competent Authority for tax treaties and TIEAs. See Delegation Order 4-12 for the current delegated offices within the Deputy Commissioner (International) (LB&I). ) The IRS can obtain information regarding entities and persons in the U.S. tories of American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Issued in (CNMI), Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands. Prior to issuing summons, however, the IRS must generally notify the tax department of territories. This notiﬁcation must be made through the LB&I U.S. Territories Program (SE:LB:IN:ADCI:TAIT) or the IRS Disclosure Office handling the territories. (

) The United States has entered into tax coordination and tax agreements with each of the territories. The requirement to notify the tax department prior to issuing a summons is found in the agreements with American Samoa, Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands. While not by the agreements with the CNMI and Guam, the IRS also provides to their tax departments before issuing a summons in those territories. (
) For more information, see the LB&I International U.S. Territories Program intranet website at http://lmsb.irs.gov/international/dir_treaty/eoi_overseas/ insular/index.asp. (

) Any IRS personnel (officer, agent, etc.) who issues any summons (direct, party, etc.) to an entity located in American Samoa, the Commonwealth of for Northern Mariana Islands (CNMI), Guam, Puerto Rico or the U.S. Virgin of Summons Islands must: a. Fax a copy of only the ﬁrst page of the summons to the Disclosure handling the U.S. Territories. The appropriate disclosure office can be located by visiting the Disclosure web site at http://discl.web.irs.gov/ contact.asp. b. If the taxpayer’s EIN/SSN is needed, the IRS can provide that in a cover document or letter as indicated in IRM
), of Information Requested; this would avoid disclosing such sensitive mation to anyone entitled to notice under IRC §

) For questions about these instructions or the Exchange of Information sions in our Tax Implementation Agreements and Tax Coordination with these three U.S. Territory jurisdictions, please contact the U.S. Program Manager (Deputy Commissioner LB&I), or the Governmental U.S. Territories. (

) The following actions should be taken by Disclosure Office personnel when serving a summons in U.S. Territories: of a. Release (fax) the summons notiﬁcation information to the appropriate Office Revenue and Tax agency; and b. Complete the necessary IRS Disclosure and Third Party Notice requirements. (
) In general, the assessment statute that applies to a corporate tax return examined under the IRS’s Coordinated Issue Case (CIC) program is Summons suspended under IRC §

(j) when a court proceeding is brought to or defend a designated or related summons issued to examine that return. suspension provision for designated and related summonses was enacted address the refusal by some corporate taxpayers to disclose information necessary to the examination, such as by transferring the records to Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
D Any line marked with is for Official Use
In general, the assessment statute that applies to a corporate tax return being examined under the IRS’s Coordinated Issue Case (CIC) program is suspended under IRC §

(j) when a court proceeding is brought to enforce or defend a designated or related summons issued to examine that return. The suspension provision for designated and related summonses was enacted to address the refusal by some corporate taxpayers to disclose information necessary to the examination, such as by transferring the records to another
page entity, and the refusal to extend the limitations period, thus forcing the IRS to issue notices of deﬁciency before fully examining the return. (

) In general, the suspension arises on and continues throughout the judicial forcement period, which begins on the day the court proceeding is brought continues until the day the summoned person fully complies with the enforce- ment order, plus an additional
days if the court orders compliance with part of the summons. If the court orders no compliance, the assessment statute will not expire before

days after the date of ﬁnal resolution. As described more fully throughout these IRM subparagraphs, the suspension provisions contain concepts, such as judicial enforcement period, ﬁnal resolution, and others, that have technical deﬁnitions which take into account several variables, such as appeal periods and collateral To fully understand and correctly determine the IRC §
(j) suspension, it necessary to read this entire IRM section and understand how each concept relates to the others. (
) For a summons to be a designated summons under IRC §

, it must satisfy the following conditions: a Designated a. A designated summons may only be issued to a corporation (or to any Meet other person to whom the corporation has transferred records) as part of an examination of the corporation’s tax return for a tax period being examined under the CIC program (or any other successor to the coordi- nated examination program); b. The Division Commissioner and the Division Counsel of the Office of Counsel (or their successors) for the organizations having examination authority over the taxpayer corporation have reviewed the summons before it is issued; c. The summons is issued and served at least
days before the day the statute of limitations on assessment expires (determined with regard to extensions); Note: In determining whether a designated summons has been issued and served at least
days before the day the statute of on assessment expires, the provisions of IRC §
apply when the last day of the assessment period falls on a Saturday, or legal holiday. d. The summons states that it is a designated summons for purposes of §
(j). Speciﬁcally, there must be a statement at the top of the summons that reads: “This is a designated summons pursuant to IRC §

) Only one designated summons may be issued for an examination of a taxable year or period. A designated summons may cover more than one taxable year or period. The designated summons may require production of information that was sought in a prior summons (other than a designated summons) issued during the examination of that particular corporation if that information was not previously produced. (
) For a summons to be a related summons under IRC §
, it must satisfy following conditions: a Related Meet (
) Internal Revenue Manual with a # Use Only

In general, the suspension arises on and continues throughout the judicial en- forcement period, which begins on the day the court proceeding is brought continues until the day the summoned person fully complies with the enforce- ment order, plus an additional
days if the court orders compliance with part of the summons. If the court orders no compliance, the assessment statute will not expire before

days after the date of ﬁnal resolution. As described more fully throughout these IRM subparagraphs, the suspension provisions contain concepts, such as judicial enforcement period, compliance, ﬁnal resolution, and others, that have technical deﬁnitions which take into account several variables, such as appeal periods and collateral proceedings. To fully understand and correctly determine the IRC §
(j) suspension, it is necessary to read this entire IRM section and understand how each concept relates to the others.

A designated summons may only be issued to a corporation (or to any other person to whom the corporation has transferred records) as part of an examination of the corporation’s tax return for a tax period being examined under the CIC program (or any other successor to the coordi- nated examination program); The Division Commissioner and the Division Counsel of the Office of Counsel (or their successors) for the organizations having examination authority over the taxpayer corporation have reviewed the summons before it is issued; The summons is issued and served at least
days before the day the statute of limitations on assessment expires (determined with regard to extensions);
a. A related summons must relate to the same corporate return as the nated summons; b. A related summons must have been issued (served) during the

-day period that begins on the day the designated summons was issued; c. A related summons can be issued to any person, including the person whom the designated summons was issued, or any third person. (
) There is no restriction on the number of related summonses that may be issued to examine the corporate return. (
) A related summons may request the same information as the designated summons, from a different witness. (
) The taxpayer corporation’s period of limitations on assessment is under IRC §
(j) during the judicial enforcement period relating to a Key to Correct nated or related summons. If the court orders any compliance with the of IRC § summons, the suspension shall continue for
days after the close of the Suspension judicial enforcement period. If the court does not order any compliance with summons, the period of limitations on assessment shall not expire before
th day after the end of the judicial enforcement period. (

) To properly apply this rule and correctly calculate the suspension period, it essential to deﬁne several concepts. They are “judicial enforcement period,” “court proceeding,” “date when proceeding is no longer pending,” “the date compliance occurs,” and “ﬁnal resolution.” (
) The judicial enforcement period is the period that begins on the day a court proceeding, deﬁned below in IRM
, Court Proceeding, is begun Enforcement with respect to a designated or related summons and ends on the day on which there is a ﬁnal resolution of the summoned person’s response to that summons. (
) A court proceeding is a proceeding ﬁled in a United States district court to quash a designated or related summons under IRC §
) or to Proceeding enforce a designated or related summons under IRC §
A court ing includes any collateral proceeding, such as a civil contempt proceeding. (
) For the period of limitations on assessment to be suspended under IRC §
(j), a court proceeding to enforce or quash a designated or related summons must be instituted within the IRC §
period of limitations on sessment that otherwise applies to the corporate tax return. (

the collateral proceeding becomes ﬁnal. The decision becomes ﬁnal on the date when all appeals (including review by the Supreme Court) are disposed or when all appeal periods or all periods for further review (including review the Supreme Court) expire. A decision in a collateral proceeding becomes when all appeals (including review by the Supreme Court) are disposed of or when all appeal periods or all periods for further review (including review by the Supreme Court) expire. (

) Compliance is the giving of testimony or the performance of an act or acts of production, or both, in response to a court order concerning the designated related summons and the determination that the terms of the court order been satisﬁed. (

) Compliance with a court order that wholly denies enforcement of a or related summons is deemed to occur on the date when all appeals (including review by the Supreme Court) are disposed of or when the period which an appeal may be taken or a request for further review (including by the Supreme Court) may be made expires. (

) Compliance with a court order that grants enforcement, in whole or in part, of designated or related summons, occurs on the date the IRS determines that the testimony given, or the books, papers, records, or other data produced, both, by the summoned party fully satisfy the court order concerning the summons. The IRS will determine whether there has been full compliance within a reasonable time, given the volume and complexity of the records produced, after the later of the giving of all testimony or the production of all records requested by the summons or required by any order enforcing any of the summons. See the following subparagraph for a further explanation examples of the reasonable time requirement that the IRS must meet when reviewing records. (

) The following are non-exclusive examples of reasonable time periods within which the IRS must determine whether the summoned corporate taxpayer or third person served with a designated or related summons has fully complied with that summons. These examples do not constitute suggested time frames because each case is different and will turn on its own facts and circum- stances: Example: The IRS served a designated summons on the corporate taxpayer to produce its records showing the original purchase price of certain

the collateral proceeding becomes ﬁnal. The decision becomes ﬁnal on the date when all appeals (including review by the Supreme Court) are disposed of or when all appeal periods or all periods for further review (including review by the Supreme Court) expire. A decision in a collateral proceeding becomes ﬁnal when all appeals (including review by the Supreme Court) are disposed of or when all appeal periods or all periods for further review (including review by the Supreme Court) expire.

The IRS served a designated summons on the corporate taxpayer to produce its records showing the original purchase price of certain capital assets acquired from a foreign vendor. The Government sued to enforce

produce its records showing the original purchase price of certain capital assets acquired from a foreign vendor. The Government sued to enforce the designated summons, and the court ordered it enforced. The taxpayer produced the records, consisting of ten pages written in English, ten months after the date the suit was ﬁled. The examiner should require no more than two business days to review the records and determine whether they are complete and whether the taxpayer has complied with the summons. Compliance occurred two business days after the taxpayer provided the records to the examiner.

Example: The IRS served a related summons on a third party to produce ten leases entered into by three foreign business entities controlled by the corporate taxpayer. The Government sued to enforce the related summons, and the court ordered it enforced. Pursuant to the enforce- ment order, the third party produces the ten documents on May
Six of the documents are written in English and are each under ten pages in
but four documents are written in an obscure foreign language total 40 pages. The IRS has no employees who can interpret the

length, but four documents are written in an obscure foreign language and total 40 pages. The IRS has no employees who can interpret the documents and must contract with an outside source to have the documents translated. The process of obtaining an outside contractor and receiving the English translation takes three months. The examiner obtains the translation on August 1 and takes ﬁve business days to review the leases and determine that they are complete and that the summons is satisﬁed. Compliance occurred ﬁve business days after August 1.

The IRS summoned a taxpayer corporation to produce all documents, described both generically and as speciﬁcally as possible in the summons, that relate to complex series of transactions among related entities. After the Government sued for enforcement and the court ordered the summons enforced, the taxpayer turned over
boxes of information, containing approximately

documents, written in The documents are not indexed, nor are they arranged in any discern- ible order. It takes a team of three revenue agents eight months to organize, catalog, and review the documents and then compare the in- formation to the summons request. Once the comparison is complete, the agents conclude that the taxpayer complied with the summons. Compliance occurred eight months after the taxpayer turned over the documents.

) b), Conditions a Designated Summons Must Meet, designated summons must be pre-reviewed by the Division Counsel and Division Commissioner for the organizations having ex- or amination authority over the taxpayer corporation. may (

) Both designated and related summonses must be pre-approved by a Field Territory Manager or Practice Area Program Manager in the area that will the summonses. a. If approved by the Territory Manager or Practice Area Program forward the summons to the Associate Area Counsel for review and dination at the area level. b. A memorandum should accompany the summons to the Territory or Practice Area Program Manager and the Associate Area Counsel, ex- plaining why the taxpayer refused to extend the statute of limitations for assessment. If the summons is to be issued near the end of the period permitted by IRC §

(j), the memorandum should explain why the summons was not issued at an earlier date. The running of the period of limitations will not be suspended under IRC

(j) if no enforcement suit is ﬁled because, for example, the desig- nated or related summons was voluntarily complied with. e. The statute of limitations will be suspended by ﬁling suit to enforce a related summons, even when the taxpayer has complied with the desig- nated summons. governs the time and place of appearance. The place of appear- ance should generally be in the nearest city with an IRS office of the same operating division (e.g. SBSE or LB&I). ) There are two types of electronic summons processes. • One method is for the examiner to both serve the summons and later retrieve the records. The examiner serves the summons by uploading the summons to the electronic portal. The third party notiﬁes the examiner by email when the records are ready for retrieval. The examiner returns to the electronic portal to retrieve the records. This process is a two-way transmission process. • The second method is to use an electronic summons process to only retrieve records. The summons is served in the normal manner (e.g. hand delivery, certiﬁed mail, or fax). The third party notiﬁes the by email when the records are ready for retrieval. The examiner retrieves the records from the electronic portal. This process is a way transmission process. (

) The employee’s email address is required to use electronic summons processes. Employees can provide the email address on the face of the summons, or provide the email address on a cover letter. The third party notiﬁcation by email when the records are ready. The third party will call the examiner if the email address is not provided on the summons or on a letter. (

) The beneﬁts for using an electronic summons process are: • Faster receipt of information • Better protection of taxpayer information • Lower cost to both the third party and to the IRS • Summoned records can be retrieved from any location • Some records are in electronic format and can be imported into a database or spreadsheet application, such as Microsoft Excel or (
) Send an email to *SBSE E-Summons Decryption Team for questions on tronic summons processes. (

) A third party may request examiners to serve the summons electronically through a summons portal or by fax. When the records are ready, the of examiner returns to the summons portal to retrieve documents See IRM
below for electronic retrieval of records. (

) Use of a summons portal to both serve a summons and later retrieve the documents electronically (a two-way transmission) requires a Memorandum Understanding (MOU) between the third party and the IRS. (
) The third party is also required to sign a waiver authorizing the IRS to elec- tronically serve the summons through the portal. The authorization waives IRC §
service requirements. (
) Use of a summons portal for two-way transmission requires formal approval from multiple business units, including IT Cybersecurity and Privacy. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
D

, Information Tech- nology (IT) Operations, Magnetic Media Management, for proper destruction of the original storage media received from the summons. Do not store the original encrypted storage media with the administrative case ﬁle. For questions, send an email to *IT Media Destruction.
There are two types of electronic summons processes.

One method is for the examiner to both serve the summons and later retrieve the records. The examiner serves the summons by uploading the summons to the electronic portal. way transmission process. The second method is to use an electronic summons process to only retrieve records. The summons is served in the normal manner (e.g. hand delivery, certiﬁed mail, or fax). The third party notiﬁes the by email when the records are ready for retrieval. The examiner retrieves the records from the electronic portal. This process is a one
way transmission process.

) The third party may request examiners to retrieve documents through an tronic summons portal. Retrieval of (
) When the records are ready for retrieval, the third party notiﬁes the by secure email. (

) Multiple emails may be sent by the third party’s summons process. One contains instructions on how to retrieve the records. A URL web link to the records is embedded in the email. A second email may be sent containing a password or passcode which is used to log into the summons portal. (

) Access to the summons portal is time limited and expires after a number of days. Examiners are encouraged to download the records to their (e.g. laptop or desktop computer) as soon as the period to quash the summons expires. (
) For additional information, refer to the job aids for approved electronic summons processes found on the M
B/SE web pages at: irs.gov/collection/toolsprocesses/Enforcement/Summons/jobaids/default.aspxandhttp://mysbse.web.irs.gov/examination/tip/summons/jobaids/default.aspx. (

) Use of a secure summons portal to only access records from a URL web does not require a MOU. If you are unsure if the summons portal is secure, Records send an email to *SBSE E-Summons Decryption Team before accessing an URL Web Links electronic summons portal through a URL web link. (

) Access to a third party secure web site to download records is allowed as as the examiner: • Has a business need to access the site; • Does not download executable ﬁles or software applications (e.g. Activ
); • Uses the site to only download records; and, • Does not upload the summons or PII data to the summons portal. (
) The third party notiﬁes the examiner by secure email when the records are ready for electronic retrieval. Examiners access the records through the link contained in the email. (

) When the examiner accesses the web site, CSIRC’s security technologies inspect the connection to ensure none of the IRS security related policies is violated. If the web site is restricted, the Block Page message displays the following information instructing the examiner how to access the restricted site:“Torequest access to a restricted web site for business purposes or to an inaccurately categorized web site, complete and submit the Internet Filtering Change Request Form.” No.

) The examiner will need to click on the Internet Content Filtering Change Request Form link contained within the Block Page message to provide the business justiﬁcation to access the web site. CSIRC processes the request to allow access to the web site to download the documents. (

) Some summons portals require the examiner to register or create an account on the summons web site prior to accessing the records. The examiner is prompted to register and create a password when they click on the link embedded in the summons process email. (

) The URL web link is typically time limited, expiring after a certain number of days. Examiners are encouraged to download the records to their (e.g. laptop or desktop computer) as soon as the period to quash the summons expires. Contact the third party to re-activate the URL web link whenever there is a delay in accessing the records. (

) Once the case investigation is complete, the electronic records need to be saved on encrypted storage media such as a CD or DVD disc. IRS security for policy requires encryption of all sensitive data stored on removable media. Case File IRM
, MP-
Media Storage, and IRM
, Portable Electronic Devices (PEDs) as Storage Media. (

) The Symantec Endpoint Encryption program, formerly known as Guardian Edge Removable Storage (GERS), includes a CD-DVD burning program that automatically encrypts all ﬁles written on CD-DVD media. For complete on using the CD/DVD burner, refer to the reference guide at gov/EDEweb/Phase
/GERS_Reference-Guide.pdf. (

, Workpapers: Closing Cases with Automated Workpapers and Reports, for the GERS password and disc labelling. (
